content.en:
Can artificial intelligence help a writer write a novel about artificial intelligence?

It can. In this case, however, it didn't. Like probably every author, I wanted what I create to be mine, not someone else's.

But...

AI saved me as a publisher from a small editorial mishap ğŸ˜‰

And it went like this. In the final phase of work with my editor, I was accepting changes and corrections. At some point I noticed that one of the changes introduced errors in a sentence. It flashed before my eyes during the review, and then I couldn't find it anymore!

And now uncertainty - was it something I corrected or is the editorial gremlin hiding somewhere insidiously in the text from my sight? I won't find it, and then it will jump out unexpectedly at the reader ğŸ¤§

Well, I have to check. But darn... read the whole thing again and look for one error... ğŸ˜©

So I took the entire content of the book and threw it to Google's Gemini 1.5 Pro model. I wrote to it that I suspect there's an error somewhere in the text, introduced by an incorrectly implemented reviewer change. The first attempt was unsuccessful. I had to correct the prompt and better explain to the model what I was looking for. The second time....

ğŸ¤”

The model told me this:

I didn't find syntax errors in the text. However, I found a place where your heroine's client's surname is incorrect because he's called X but here we have Y...

It was true, as part of the last edition I changed this character's surname. I did it very carefully, replacing all occurrences and searching by root, so that declension wouldn't cause me to miss any place. However, there was one occurrence of the old version of this surname that had a typo in it. That's why my search missed that place.
